if you use ALSA, then you have no OSS.  you have only "OSS Emulation" which simply means ALSA converts requests for OSS sound into normal ALSA requests
meaning dmix will mix both for you
and neither one are needed if your soundcard can mix multiple sounds in hardware.  mine for example can mix 12 in hardware.  some cheaper soundcards only do software mixing

so it will be like Windows 2000 and above: you can always play more than one sound at a time, no matter what soundcard you have.  Gnome uses ESD, KDE uses ARTS.  its their way of making sure people don't have the "only one sound at a time" issue
dmix is not usually set up
ESD and ARTS are part of the Gnome and KDE packages.  they aren't related to ALSA in any way
I have no idea if Ubuntu sets up dmix by default, but most distros do not.  if it is set up, then esd should not be needed.  try this: mv /usr/bin/esd /tmp; kill $(ps auxww|awk '/esd/ {print $2}')
then see if you can still play more than one sound at a time.  if not, mv /tmp/esd /usr/bin
you'll need "sudo" before those 'mv' commands, as they need to be done by root
did you also kill the processes with that ps|awk command ?
it will still be running even if you move the exe file
